CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 24, 1946, pg. 10, reads: "WEDS FIREMAN - Miss Pauline heater of Cincinnati, Ohio, was married to James E. Moore, city fireman, last Saturday in a charming ceremony performed at the home of the best man, Howard Spencer. Pictured are Miss Joan Heater, bridesmaid; Charles Brown, the bride and groom, and Howard Spencer. - Harris Photo."  Accompanying article reads: "Miss Pauline Heater Weds James E. Moore - Miss Pauline Heater of Cincinnati, Ohio, was married Saturday, Aug. 17, to City Fireman James E. Moore, known for his melodious voice.  Attending the bride was Miss Joan Heater as bridesmaid, while Howard Spencer was best man.  The Rev. Cornell Talley performed the ceremony which was attended by a number of firemen officials and members of the bride's family from Ohio.  Wearing a pink chiffon afternoon dress, the bride chose pink roses for her hair.  The firemen there included Deputy Chief McDermont of the downtown office; Earl Barnett, William Thomas, William Pearsell of No. 58 Engine Company; Jack Harrison, George Velar and Claude Morris of 25 Engine Company.  Bride's Mother is Present.  The bride's relatives were present, all from Cincinnati, were Mrs. Ida Heater, her mother; Mr. and Mrs. Paul Heater Jr., Clarence Heater, Walter Heater, Miss Joan Heater and Mrs. Florence Heater Brown and daughter, Gwendolyn.  Mrs. Brown is the wife of the Ohio 'Onion King,' producer of one of the largest onion crops in Ohio.  The ceremony was performed at the home of the best man, Howard Spencer, on the back lawn beneath and arch of flowers.  Out-of-town guests included Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Seniors of Cincinnati; Mrs. Mary Warren, sister of the groom; and Mr. and Mrs. John Moore, brother of the groom, all of Springfield, Ohio, and Mr. and Mrs. W. Clark."
TitMainTitle: Wedding ceremony with groom James E. Moore kissing bride Pauline Heater Moore wearing dress with face and bow pattern, Rev. Cornell Talley standing on right, and Charles Brown in background, posed under trellis, in yard of Howard Spencer
